title: US (MEDPED) Diagnostic Criteria for Familial Hypercholesterolemia (FH)
description: Diagnoses familial hypercholesterolemia using age-specific total cholesterol cutoff values that vary based on family history of FH. The US MEDPED (Make Early Diagnosis to Prevent Early Death) criteria provide a simplified approach to FH diagnosis using only total cholesterol levels and family history.

result.name: medped_diagnosis
result.description: US MEDPED diagnostic result for familial hypercholesterolemia

ranges.description: Meets US MEDPED criteria for FH
ranges.interpretation: Patient meets the US MEDPED diagnostic criteria for familial hypercholesterolemia. Total cholesterol level exceeds the age and family history-specific cutoff. Consider genetic testing, family screening, and initiation of lipid-lowering therapy.

ranges.description: Does not meet US MEDPED criteria for FH
ranges.interpretation: Patient does not meet the US MEDPED diagnostic criteria for familial hypercholesterolemia. Total cholesterol level is below the age and family history-specific cutoff. Consider other causes of hypercholesterolemia if cholesterol is elevated.

references: Williams RR, Hunt SC, Schumacher MC, et al. Diagnosing heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia using new practical criteria focused on the family history. Am J Cardiol. 1993;72(2):171-176.
Stone NJ, Levy RI, Fredrickson DS, Verter J. Coronary artery disease in 116 kindred with familial type II hyperlipoproteinemia. Circulation. 1974;49(3):476-488.
MEDPED Program. Make Early Diagnosis to Prevent Early Death (MEDPED). University of Utah. Available at: https://www.medped.org/
formula:
Age-specific total cholesterol cutoffs:
- Age <20: 1st degree 220, 2nd degree 230, 3rd degree 240, general population 270 mg/dL
- Age 20-29: 1st degree 240, 2nd degree 250, 3rd degree 260, general population 290 mg/dL
- Age 30-39: 1st degree 270, 2nd degree 280, 3rd degree 290, general population 340 mg/dL
- Age ≥40: 1st degree 290, 2nd degree 300, 3rd degree 310, general population 360 mg/dL
Diagnosis: Positive if total cholesterol ≥ corresponding cutoff
notes: The US MEDPED criteria use only total cholesterol and family history, making them simpler to apply than other FH diagnostic tools.
Lower cholesterol cutoffs are used when there is a family history of FH (1st, 2nd, or 3rd degree relatives).
These criteria were designed for population screening and early diagnosis to prevent early cardiovascular death.
Consider genetic testing and cascade screening of family members if criteria are met.
The MEDPED criteria may be less sensitive than the Dutch Lipid Clinic Network criteria but are easier to apply in clinical practice.
